s.text: Since oil prices are prospective, the markets do not anticipate a global slowdown any time soon.
Since oil prices are prospective, the markets do not anticipate a global slowdown any time soon.

And here's where the "foregone conclusion" looks a little less foregone, primarily because both OPEC and non-member countries, such as Mexico and Norway, have shown restraint in the face of rising prices.

In an earlier incarnation of this column, in fact, I argued that the combination of new oil-discovery and oil-recovery technology with the advent of the spot futures market in oil meant that the OPEC's glory days were long gone.

In fact, the oil companies appear to be planning on prices between $20 and $25 a barrel, which would mean that while filling up your tank is going to be more expensive than it was nine months ago, any inflationary impact from oil prices will be seriously muted.
